variant.question: To eliminate a tendency to tuck under, the Mach Trim System:

options.text: Reduces the incidence of the tail
Moves the CG forward by pumping fuel towards the front of the aircraft
Deflects the elevators downwards
Reduces the value of stick force stability to zero at speeds above Mcrit

variant.question: An aeroplane should be equipped with a Mach trimmer, if:

options.text: at transonic mach numbers the aeroplane displays an unacceptable decrease in longitudinal stick force stability.
stick force stability becomes independent of IAS and altitude.
stick force per g strongly decreases at low Mach numbers.
at high IAS and low altitude the aeroplane displays an unacceptable decrease in longitudinal stick force stability.

variant.question: An aeroplane should be equipped with a Mach trimmer, if:

options.text: delayed; a higher
delayed; a lower
an earlier; a lower
an earlier; a higher

variant.question: Tuck under may happen at:

options.text: high Mach numbers.
low Mach numbers.
all Mach numbers.
only at low altitudes.

variant.question: "Tuck under" can occur:

options.text: only above the critical Mach number.
only below the critical Mach number.
above or below the critical Mach number depending on the angle of attack.
only at the critical Mach number.

variant.question: "Tuck under" can occur:

options.text: only above the critical Mach number.
above or below the critical Mach number depending on the angle of attack.
only at high altitudes.
only below the critical Mach number.

variant.question:
Which of these statements about tuck under are correct or incorrect?

1. Tuck under is caused by an aft movement of the centre of pressure of the wing.

2. Tuck under is caused by a reduction in the downwash angle at the location of the horizontal stabiliser.

options.text: I is correct, II is correct.
I is correct, II is incorrect.
I is incorrect, II is correct.
I is incorrect, II is incorrect.

variant.question: The Mach trim system will prevent:

options.text: tuck under.
shock stall.
dutch roll.
buffeting.

variant.question: A Mach trimmer:

options.text: corrects insufficient stick force stability at high Mach numbers.
is necessary for compensation of the autopilot at high Mach numbers.
increases the stick force per G at high Mach numbers.
has no effect on the shape of the elevator position versus speed (IAS) curve for a fully hydraulic controlled aeroplane.

variant.question: A Mach trimmer:

options.text: corrects insufficient stick force stability at high Mach numbers.
has no effect on the shape of the elevator position versus speed (IAS) curve for a fully hydraulically controlled aeroplane.
is necessary for compensation of the autopilot at high Mach numbers.
increases the stick force per g at high Mach numbers.

variant.question: To compensate for tuck under effect, what action could be taken by the Mach trim system?

options.text: Decrease the incidence of the variable incidence trimming tailplane.
Deflect the elevator down in order to create a nose-down pitching moment.
Move the CG forward by transferring fuel from the rear trim tank to the wing tanks.
Reduce the stick force stability to zero above Mcrit.

variant.question: To compensate for tuck under effect, what action could be taken by the Mach trim system?

options.text: Decrease the incidence of the variable incidence trimming tailplane.
Deflect the elevator down in order to create a nose-down pitching moment.
Move the CG forward by transferring fuel from the rear trim tank to the wing tanks.
Reduce the stick force stability to zero above Mcrit.

variant.question: The Mach-trim function is installed on most commercial jets in order to minimise the adverse effects of:

options.text: changes in the position of centre of pressure.
increased drag due to shock wave formation.
uncontrolled changes in stabiliser setting.
compressibility effects on the stabiliser.

variant.question: Which of the following statements about a Mach trimmer is correct?

options.text: A Mach trimmer corrects the change in stick force stability of a swept wing aeroplane above a certain Mach number.
A straight wing aeroplane always needs a Mach trimmer for flying at Mach numbers close to MMO.
The Mach trimmer corrects the natural tendency of a swept wing aeroplane to pitch up.
A Mach trimmer reduces the stick force stability of a straight wing aeroplane to zero at high Mach numbers.

variant.question: Which of the following statements about a Mach trimmer is correct?

options.text: A Mach trimmer corrects the change in stick force stability of a swept wing aeroplane above a certain Mach number.
The Mach trimmer corrects the natural tendency of a swept wing aeroplane to pitch-up.
A Mach trimmer reduces the stick force stability of a straight wing aeroplane to zero at high Mach numbers.
A straight wing aeroplane always needs a Mach trimmer for flying at Mach numbers close to MMO.

variant.question: On a conventional airfoil, which of the following will reduce the critical Mach number?

options.text: Increased leading edge radius.
A thin airfoil.
Reduced thickness to chord ratio.
Reduced angle of attack.

variant.question: As the Mach number increases from subsonic to supersonic, the centre of pressure moves:

options.text: to the mid chord position.
forward.
to a position near the trailing edge.
to a position near the leading edge.

variant.question: The Mach trim system will:

options.text: adjust the stabiliser, depending on the Mach number.
adjust the elevator trim tab, depending on the Mach number.
keep the Mach number automatically constant.
pump the fuel from tank to tank, depending on the Mach number.

variant.question: The Mach trim system will:

options.text: adjust the stabilizer, depending on the Mach number.
keep the Mach number automatically constant.
pump the fuel from tank to tank, depending on the Mach number.
adjust the elevator trim tab, depending on the Mach number.

variant.question: 'Tuck under' is the?

options.text: nose down pitching tendency as speed is increased in the transonic range.
nose up pitching tendency as speed is increased in the transonic range.
nose down pitching tendency when the control column is pulled rearwards.
shaking of the control column at high Mach number.

variant.question: The Mach trim system is able to compensate for the tuck under effect by:

options.text: decreasing the incidence of the trimmable tailplane.
deflecting the elevator down to generate a nose-down pitching moment.
reducing the stick force stability to zero if the speed is above Mcrit.
moving the CG to a forward location by transferring fuel from the rear trim tank to the wing tanks.

variant.question: Two methods to increase the critical Mach number are

options.text: thin aerofoils and sweepback of the wing.
positive cambering of the aerofoil and sweepback of the wing.
thick aerofoils and dihedral of the wing.
thin aerofoils and dihedral of the wing.

variant.question: In the event of a Mach trimmer failure, what is the appropriate course of action?

options.text: The Mach number must be limited.
The Mach number be increased.
The Mach number be decreased.
You should switch to V~MO~.

variant.question: What does a Mach trim do?

options.text: Prevents the aircraft having a nose down moment.
Prevents the aircraft trim moving in response to travel through the transonic range.
Creates an automatic trim response as the aircraft’s CG moves upon passing through the transonic range.
Prevents the aircraft having a nose up moment.

variant.question: On a typical transonic airfoil the transonic rearward shift of the Centre of Pressure (CP) occurs at about:

options.text: Mach 0.89 to Mach 0.98
Mach 0.75 to Mach 0.98
Mach 0.91 to Mach 1.4
Mach 0.75 to Mach 0.89

variant.question: In the event of failure of the Mach trimmer:

options.text: the Mach number must be limited.
the aeroplane mass must be limited.
the centre of gravity must be moved aft.
the speed must be kept constant.

variant.question:
Which of the following methods can be applied to counter "Mach Tuck"?
I.   Moving CG backwards.
2.  Moving CG forwards.
III. Automatic pitch trim to pitch nose up.
IIII.Automatic pitch trim to pitch nose down.

options.text: I and III.
I and IIII.
II and III
II and IIII.

variant.question: Which of the following methods could be applied to counter mach tuck? - Shifting CG rearwards - Shifting CG forwards - Automatic pitch trim to pitch nose down - Automatic pitch trim to nose up

options.text: 1 and 4
1 and 3
2 and 3
2 and 4

variant.question: Consider an aircraft at high subsonic speeds requiring a Mach trim system. How could this trim be provided?

options.text: By reducing the incidence of the tailplane.
Deflecting the elevator downwards.
By moving fuel from the rear of the aircraft to the front.
Increasing the tailplane incidence.

variant.question: "Tuck under" is caused by ___ movement of the centre of pressure (CP) of the wing and ___ downwash angle at the location of the stabilizer.

options.text: an aft; a decreasing
a forward; an increasing
an aft; an increasing
a forward; a decreasing

variant.question: What does the Mach trim system use to prevent 'Mach tuck'?

options.text: elevator
rudder
elevator/aileron/rudder
elevator/rudder

variant.question: What is the value of the Mach number if the Mach angle equals 45°?

Which of the following methods can be applied to counter "Mach Tuck"?

1. Shifting CG backwards.
2. Shifting CG forwards.
III. Automatic pitch trim to pitch nose up.
IV. Automatic pitch trim to pitch nose down.

options.text: I and III.
II and IV.
I and IV.
II and III.

variant.question:
Refer to figure 081-24.
Which statement is correct regarding the pitching moment coefficient C~m~ versus angle of attack diagram?

options.text: Line 4 shows an aeroplane with increasing static longitudinal stability at very high angles of attack.
Line 4 shows an aeroplane with a greater static longitudinal stability at low angles of attack than that shown in line 3.
Line 1 shows an aeroplane with increasing static longitudinal instability at very high angles of attack.
Line 3 shows an aeroplane with increasing static longitudinal stability at high angles of attack.

variant.question:
Refer to figure 081-24.
Which statement is correct regarding the pitching moment coefficient C~m~ versus angle of attack diagram?

options.text: Line 3 shows an aeroplane with reducing static longitudinal stability at high angles of attack.
Line 4 shows an aeroplane with reducing static longitudinal stability at very high angles of attack.
Line 1 shows an aeroplane with increasing static longitudinally instability at very high angles of attack.
Line 4 shows an aeroplane with greater static longitudinal stability at low angles of attack than that in shown line 3.

variant.question:
Refer to figure 081-24.
Which statement is correct regarding the pitching moment coefficient C~m~ versus angle of attack diagram?

options.text: Line 1 shows an aeroplane with reducing static longitudinal instability at very high angles of attack.
Line 4 shows an aeroplane with a greater static longitudinal stability at low angles of attack than that shown in line 3.
Line 4 shows an aeroplane with reducing static longitudinal stability at very high angles of attack.
Line 3 shows an aeroplane with increasing static longitudinal stability at high angles of attack.

variant.question:
Refer to figure 081-24.
Which statement is correct regarding the pitching moment coefficient C~m~ versus angle of attack diagram?

options.text: Line 3 shows an aeroplane with greater static longitudinal stability at low angles of attack than that shown in line 4.
Line 4 shows an aeroplane with reducing static longitudinal stability at very high angles of attack.
Line 1 shows an aeroplane with increasing static longitudinal instability at very high angles of attack.
Line 3 shows an aeroplane with increasing static longitudinal stability at high angles of attack.

variant.question: Which of these statements about the pitching moment coefficient versus angle of attack lines in the annex is correct?

options.text: The CG position is further aft at line 1 when compared with line 4.
In its curved part at high angles of attack line 2 illustrates a decreasing static longitudinal stability.
The CG position is further forward at line 1 when compared with line 4.
Static longitudinal stability is greater at line 3 when compared with line 4 at low and moderate angles of attack.

options.text: The CG position is further aft at line 1 when compared with line 4.
Static longitudinal stability is greater at line 3 when compared with line 4 at low and moderate angles of attack.
In its curved part at high angles of attack line 2 illustrates a decreasing static longitudinal stability.
The CG position is further forward at line 1 when compared with line 4.

 Which of these statements about the pitching moment coefficient versus angle of attack lines in the annex is correct?

The CG position is further aft at line 4 when compared with line 1.

options.text: Static longitudinal stability is greater at line 4 when compared with line 3 at low and moderate angles of attack.
Static longitudinal stability is greater at line 3 compared with line 4 at low and moderate angles of attack.
The CG position is further forward at line 1 when compared with line 4.

variant.question: In an aircraft where the CP is positioned behind the CG:

options.text:
The L/W couple must be balanced by a nose up T/D couple
or a down force from the tailplane

The L/W couple must be balanced by a nose down T/D couple
or a down force from the tailplane

The L/W couple must be balanced by a nose down T/D couple
or a up force from the tailplane

The L/W couple must be balanced by a nose up T/D couple
or a up force from the tailplane
